awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Mechanisms of Heat-Induced Loss of Host Plant Resistance to Insects
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Fayetteville State University (FSU) will conduct research aimed at understanding host plant (wheat; Triticum aestivum) and parasite (Hessian fly; Mayetiola destructor) interactions. This project will greatly improve the quality of undergraduate research and education in biological Sciences and the four-year graduation rate at FSU which is currently less than 20%. In addition, results from this study may help wheat breeders develop wheat cultivars to enhance the production of the agriculture industry and benefit the rural community in the U.S. Therefore, this study may have a major impact on society since wheat is an important food crop in the US and the world and the Hessian fly is one of the most destructive pests of wheat in North America and North Africa. 

The goal of the proposed study is to reveal the molecular mechanism of heat-induced loss of plant resistance using wheat-Hessian fly interaction as a model. The specific objectives of the proposed research are to: 1) determine the impact of heat stress on interactions between different wheat resistance genes (R genes) and Hessian fly biotypes; 2) examine heat-induced genome-wide changes in gene expression in wheat using high throughput molecular technologies, and 3) identify genes and pathways that possibly contribute to the heat-induced loss of wheat resistance. The findings from the research will enhance understanding of the molecular mechanism of the heat-induced loss of resistance in plants and co-evolution between host plants and parasites. This project will be conducted in collaboration with faculty from North Carolina State University.

por.por_cntn:
Outcome addressing intellectual merit

Understand how and why heat stress compromises plant resistance to insect pests is important for our understanding of coevolution of plants with their insect pests under the context of climate change and global warming. In this research, we used the interaction between common bread wheat and its pest, Hessian fly as model to understand the mechanisms of heat-induced loss of host plant resistance to insects. To this end, firstly, we infested two resistant wheat cultivars ?Molly? and ?Caldwell? containing the resistance genes H13 and H6, respectively, with an avirulent Hessian fly biotype GP and treated the plants with different temperatures to examine the impact of heat stress on their resistance phenotypes. Secondly, we treated Molly wheat seedlings with Hessian fly infestation, heat stress, and the combination of heat stress and Hessian fly infestation. Tissue samples collected from Hessian fly feeding sites in the Molly plants were subjected to RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis to determine the effect of heat stress on gene expression profile in wheat plants. Via statistical analysis of phenotyping data and statistical and bioinformatical analyses of data generated from RNA-Seq, the following findings are revealed:  

1) Wheat resistance conferred by the resistance gene H6 were compromised by heat stress at lower temperatures than that of H13, suggesting that different Hessian fly resistance genes possess different levels of sensitivity to heat stress.

2) Over 14,000 differentially expressed genes are identified due to heat, Hessian fly, and/or the combination of heat and Hessian fly infestation.  The analysis of these data suggests that short period of heat stress, alone or in combination with heat stress, exert significant impact on gene expression in wheat plants.

3) Wheat plants exposed to heat stress are more sensitive to Hessian fly infestation than plants without heat stress, and wheat plants infested by Hessian fly are more responsive to heat stress in their gene expression, which implies that increased temperature due to climate change could make our crop plants more vulnerable to insect pests.

4) Pertaining the mechanisms of the heat-induced loss of wheat resistance to Hessian fly,  our data suggest that heat stress may impair the processes in wheat plants that produce and mobilize chemical resources needed for synthesizing defensive compounds, weaken cell wall and cuticle defense, decrease plant hormone 12-oxo-phytodienoic acid (OPDA) signaling, but increase plant hormone auxin signaling, leading to the suppressed resistance and activation of susceptibility to the infesting Hessian fly.

5) We identified seven genes that may contribute to wheat resistance to Hessian fly at early stage of wheat-Hessian fly interaction and 16 genes that may contribute to the heat-induced loss of wheat resistance. Further studies of the function of these genes will take our understanding of the mechanism of wheat resistance and heat-induced loss of wheat resistance to Hessian fly to the next level.

Outcome pertaining to broader impacts

The focus of our broader impact activity was to engage students at Fayetteville state university (FSU)-a minority serving institution in the process of scientific discovery and communication. 10 students have been trained in this project, which included five minority students, eight female students, and one active military student. Three students have presented and/or co-authored six presentations in professional conferences/settings. Two students co-authored a publication in the Journal of Economic Entomology. The experiences and training in this research project have helped these students broaden their knowledge, apply what they've learned from textbook and classroom in research, improve their ability in problem solving and critical thinking, increase their confidence, find their career passion, and enhance their professional competitiveness to enter graduate school and STEM workforce. To date, four students involved in this project have entered graduate schools and one entered STEM workforce. Also, the project brought, the first time, the large scale functional genomic study into the campus of FSU and exposed students to a wealth of data generated by the next generation sequencing technology. The discovery made by this project enhanced the reputation of FSU in scientific community. Through completing this project, we updated our equipment and technology, which strengthened the research capability at FSU. Additionally, the findings of this project will provide new insights to breeders in developing wheat cultivars with durable resistance to Hessian fly under changed environments and increased temperature.

The products of the project include:

1) Two scholarlily publications. One has been published and the other is currently under review.

2) 15 scholarly presentations in international, national, regional, and local professional conferences/settings

3) 981million RNA sequencing data, which has been submitted to NCBI BioProject database (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/) with accession number PRJNA589693. The data provide a wealth of information for scientists and citizens to analyze and answer scientific questions beyond the scope of this research project.
